rev.diff:
Line 465: Line 465:
===People's Republic of China===
===People's Republic of China===
[[File:Voa beijing 230 20feb11.jpg|thumb|The largely silent crowd gathered in front of a [[McDonalds]] restaurant near [[Tiananmen Square]] in [[Beijing]].]]
[[File:Voa beijing 230 20feb11.jpg|thumb|The largely silent crowd gathered in front of a [[McDonalds]] restaurant near [[Tiananmen Square]] in [[Beijing]].]]
  +
{{main|Jasmine Revolution in China}}
There were calls made via social networks such as ''Twitter'' to begin a "Jasmine Revolution" in China. [[Government of the People's Republic of China|Chinese authorities]] arrested activists, increased the normal police presence, disabled some [[Mobile phone industry in China|cell phone]] [[text messaging]] services and [[Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China|deleted Internet postings]] about protests planned for 14:00 on 20 February in [[Beijing]], [[Shanghai]] and 11 other cities.<ref name="China tries to stamp out">{{cite news| url= http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-02-20-china-jasmine-revolution_N.htm| title= China tries to stamp out 'Jasmine Revolution'| publisher= [[usatoday.com]]| date= 20 Feb 2011| accessdate= }}</ref> On the day of the protests, the police turned out en masse to all of the potential protest locations in various cities around the country.<ref name="NYChina">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/21/world/asia/21china.html|title=Chinese Security Officials Respond to Call for Protests|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|author=Jacob, Andrew|date=2011-02-20|accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> Small crowds, including quite a few curious onlookers, gathered at the planned site in [[Beijing]] and [[Shanghai]] but did not chant slogans or hold signs.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/8336611/China-snuffs-out-democracy-protests.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first1=Peter | last1=Foster | first2=Malcolm | last2=Moore | title=China snuffs out democracy protests | date=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12517909 | work=BBC News | title=China police break up 'protests' after online appeal | date=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iblKmk0zFyrloDdKUWP56cuOfD2Q?docId=CNG.7a0509e93accafbdfd4785aad6cc3018.5b1| title=China cracks down after calls for protests| first=Robert| last=Saiget| work=AFP| publisher=Google| date=February 20, 2011| accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/20/us-china-protests-idUSTRE71J0TV20110220 | work=Reuters | title=Chinese police snuff out planned Arab-inspired protests | date=2011-02-20}}</ref> [[CPC General Secretary]] and President [[Hu Jintao]] responded by calling top leaders into a "study session" to root out and tackle social issues before they "become threats to stability".<ref name="NYChina"/> In a speech at the [[Central Party School of the Communist Party of China|Central Party School]], Hu called out for tighter restrictions to the internet.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703498804576156203874160350.html?mod=googlenews_wsj|title=Call for Protests Unnerves China|author=Page, Jeremy|date=2011-02-20|accessdate=2011-02-20|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref>
There were calls made via social networks such as ''Twitter'' to begin a "Jasmine Revolution" in China. [[Government of the People's Republic of China|Chinese authorities]] arrested activists, increased the normal police presence, disabled some [[Mobile phone industry in China|cell phone]] [[text messaging]] services and [[Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China|deleted Internet postings]] about protests planned for 14:00 on 20 February in [[Beijing]], [[Shanghai]] and 11 other cities.<ref name="China tries to stamp out">{{cite news| url= http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-02-20-china-jasmine-revolution_N.htm| title= China tries to stamp out 'Jasmine Revolution'| publisher= [[usatoday.com]]| date= 20 Feb 2011| accessdate= }}</ref> On the day of the protests, the police turned out en masse to all of the potential protest locations in various cities around the Times]]''|author=Jacob, Andrew|date=2011-02-20|accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref> Small crowds, including quite a few curious onlookers, gathered at the planned site in [[Beijing]] and [[Shanghai]] but did not chant slogans or hold signs.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/8336611/China-snuffs-out-democracy-protests.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first1=Peter | last1=Foster | first2=Malcolm | last2=Moore | title=China snuffs out democracy protests | date=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12517909 | work=BBC News | title=China police break up 'protests' after online appeal | date=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iblKmk0zFyrloDdKUWP56cuOfD2Q?docId=CNG.7a0509e93accafbdfd4785aad6cc3018.5b1| title=China cracks down after calls for protests| first=Robert| last=Saiget| work=AFP| publisher=Google| date=February 20, 2011| accessdate=2011-02-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/20/us-china-protests-idUSTRE71J0TV20110220 | work=Reuters | title=Chinese police snuff out planned Arab-inspired protests | date=2011-02-20}}</ref> [[CPC General Secretary]] and President [[Hu Jintao]] responded by calling top leaders into a "study session" to root out and tackle social issues before they "become threats to stability".<ref name="NYChina"/> In a speech at the [[Central Party School of the Communist Party of China|Central Party School]], Hu called out for tighter restrictions to the internet.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703498804576156203874160350.html?mod=googlenews_wsj|title=Call for Protests Unnerves China|author=Page, Jeremy|date=2011-02-20|accessdate=2011-02-20|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref>
